Algae, tiny single-celled plants, also grow in the clam?s flesh and produce nutrients which the clam can use.

This specimen was originally part of the butterfly collection of J.J. Joicey, who had a large collection of birdwing butterflies at his private museum, the Hill Museum, in Surrey.

NarNarrative: Chitons are a type of mollusc often found on the seashore in the intertidal zone. Instead of having a single shell they have eight separate shell plates. This allows them to be much more flexible than other shellfish, and they cling tightly to the surface as they creep slowly across rocks, grazing on algae and microorganisms. Their head is hidden on the underside of their body. They are usually most active at night or when the tide is high.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: This species is a small and colourful gastropod snail. It grows up to about 3cm high. It grazes on algae and can be found on seaweed covered rocks from the shoreline down to depths of about 300m in offshore waters. The body of the snail is often very colourful, and can be flecked with red, purple or yellow.

NarNarrative: The Green Sea Urchin is found amongst rocks and seaweed on the lower shore. It is generally green in colour and covered in short purple tipped spines. Large specimens can grow up to 6cm across, but is generally much smaller than this. It feeds on a variety of animals and plants on the shore. It is also an important grazing animal, controlling the growth of seaweed. The test, which is the shell-like exoskeleton, is often washed up on the beach.
SciName: echinoidea & & Psammechinus miliaris : : : : Echinodermata

NarNarrative: This is one of the largest brittlestars found in British waters. It prefers rocky and stony places on the coast. It varies in colour from dark grey or brown to red, yellow and sometimes white. It often has alternating bands of colour on it's arms. It is a scavenger and feeds on decaying plant and animal remains. In deeper water the brittlestars often gather together into vast colonies called 'brittlestar beds'.
SciName: Ophiuroidea & Ophiothricidae & Ophiothrix fragilis : : : : Echinodermata

NarNarrative: Asterina gibbosa is a small starfish with five short arms. It scavenges for food amongst rocks and seaweed, eating both plant and animal matter and even other, smaller, starfish. Like all starfish, it walks on hundreds of tiny tube feet, appearing to glide over the surface as it moves. When it finds something edible it pushes its stomach out through its mouth and digests the food externally before moving on.
SciName: Asteroidea & & Asterina gibbosa : : : : Echinodermata

NarNarrative: The Prickly cockle is a large species that lives in shallow water all around the British coast. Unlike many coastal shellfish, it doesn't bury itself deep in the sand, and lives just beneath the surface, where it filters food particles out of the water. The Prickly Cockle can jump to escape from predators using it's large muscular foot. This can be rapidly extended to propel the animal up to 20 cm across the surface.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: The Thin Tellin is a small bivalve that is found in coastal areas throughout Europe. It is particularly common in estuaries. It prefers sandy areas with lots of wave action to stir up the sediment that it feeds on. It's thin and delicate shell is glossy and often colourful, ranging from pink to yellow and brown. This species is a popular shellfish for eating throughout the Mediterranean.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: This species is common in coastal sand and mudflats. It burrows to a depth of about 20cm below the surface and is often found in estuaries. It feeds by extending a long siphon up to the surface of the seabed. It sucks in seawater and filters out the organic particles in it. The siphon often extends above the surface, and is sometimes nipped off by crabs and passing fish. However, the shellfish can re-grow it in a just few days.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Berwick upon Tweed, Holy Island

SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

Specimens from the Bering Sea in the Canadian Arctic grow up to 18 cm long. Like most bivalves this species lives buried in the seabed and feeds by filtering organic particles out of the water. This specimen was collected in deep water offshore of the river Tyne.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England)

NarNarrative: This shell belongs to a species of whelk. It is found in deep cold waters throughout the North Sea, north Atlantic and the Arctic Sea. Specimens have been collected off the coast of Norway, Iceland, Greenland and islands in the Canadian arctic. This specimen was collected at sea about 130 miles north east of Newcastle. It lives at a wide range of depths, from less than 20m to over 450m, and grows to about 10cm long.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalPrecise: Tyne, River (120-139 miles east by north of)

NarNarrative: The Red Whelk is common at scattered sites around the northern British Isles. It is a large species that lives in shallow waters just offshore. It's shell is often washed up on the beach. It looks very similar to the larger common whelk, but unlike this species it cannot be eaten. Because this species prefers cooler conditions, there is some concern that climate change could affect the abundance of this species in British waters.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: The Black Clam is a large bivalve mollusc that is found throughout the arctic, European waters and the Atlantic coast of North America. It burrows into soft sand and mud. It is slow growing and some individuals live for over 100 years. The clam is preyed on by starfish and also the Wolf fish, a species with jaws strong enough to crack open it's thick shell. Several thousand tons are also fished annually in North America for human consumption.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: This large species of mussel is found throughout Europe where they are native to slow flowing rivers, lakes and streams. They are particularly common in canals. They feed mainly on sediment and organic particles in the water. They can grow to about 10 centimetres long. Freshwater mussels produce parasitic larvae called glochidia that can swim. These larvae burrow into the flesh of passing fish, where they live for a few weeks before dropping off and growing into an adult.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Prestwick Carr

NarNarrative: This species lives in fast flowing rivers and streams throughout Europe and North America. It has a strange life cycle. When the larvae hatch they can swim, and attach themselves to the gills of fish. After a year they drop off and settle onto the river bed where they grow into adults. They can live for over 100 years and don't start to reproduce until they are 12 years old. Unfortunately they are threatened with extinction, mainly due to pollution.
SciName: Mollusca & Pelecypoda & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: This species is found throughout Britain except for parts of northern Scotland. It lives in a variety of habitats but prefers dryer conditions. It is common on sand dunes. The shell of this species has a very variable colour pattern ranging from almost black to white and sometimes has dark or pale stripes. Snails with stripes are more common in grassy areas where their markings give them camouflage, whereas snails without stripes tend to be more common in woodland areas.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Newbiggin by the Sea

NarNarrative: This is one of the most familiar seashore animals. It can be found all around the British coast. At low tide, they are often seen attached to rocks and stones, or feeding in rock pools on green seaweed and micro-organisms. They form an important source of food for larger animals such as crabs. As its name suggests, in some areas this species was traditionally collected by hand for food.
SciName: Mollusca & Gastropoda & & : : : : Mollusca

NarNarrative: The mussel is a well-known animal found all along Britain's coast. The mussel lives in large colonies, called beds. Smaller clusters of mussels can often also be found on rocks along the shore. They attach themselves to the surface of the rock by tough, fibrous byssus threads which can withstand strong waves. Mussels are filter feeders, so tend to live in areas where the water contains lots of silt.
SciName: Mollusca & Pelecypoda & & : : : : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Roker

NarNarrative: This butterfly is a very adaptable species native to upland regions of South East Asia from India to Singapore. It occurs very locally, but can be extremely common in those areas, and thrives in a wide variety of environments. The caterpillars feed on several species of Fig tree as well as the Kalios tree, Streblus asper, and the Indian Plum tree, Flacourtia rukam.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species lives in South East Asia from Bengal in India to Sulawesi in Indonesia. It is a widespread member of the Milkweed butterfly family, which also contains the familiar orange and black American Monarch. It can be found in mature rainforest, coastal mangrove forests and also in cleared areas where the forest is regenerating. It is very distasteful to predators - the caterpillars feed on Billygoat Weed, Ageratum conyzoides and other weedy plants such as the creeper Raphistemma pulchellum.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Danadae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is from Burma, but the species is found from India as far as the South East Asian islands. It is a large, slow flying forest species with a wingspan of about 6 cm. It prefers undisturbed primary rainforest. It is very distasteful to predators, and many other species of butterfly mimic its wing patterns. The caterpillar feeds on a variety of plants in the Milkweed family such as Indian Cockle, Cocculus indicus.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The White Dragontail is the smallest member of the Swallowtail family. It lives in eastern Asia, from northern China to Indonesia. It is a very fast and erratic flyer and is sometimes compared to a tiny dragonfly. It usually stays on the wing and very rarely lands on vegetation. Small groups of this species are often seen circling around puddles or flowering bushes. The caterpillars feed on the forest shrub Illigera celebica. This specimen was collected in Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: These small and very distinctive butterflies are found across eastern Asia from northern India to China and the Indonesian islands. They are fast flying forest butterflies, and can sometimes be mistaken for other species because their tails are not always visible in flight. In Malaysia and Singapore this species is known as Itamputi from the Malay words "hitam", meaning black, and "putih", meaning white.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a fast flying butterfly found over much of southern Asia from India to Australia. There are lots of different subspecies. Its a forest species and is often seen flying in groups with other butterflies. Males often congregate in large groups around puddles or dung on the forest floor. The caterpillars of this species feed on plants in the Cinnamon family.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is widespread in eastern Asia, and there are several sub-species found across the region. They are forest butterflies, and the adults feed on nectar. They are often seen along jungle paths around flowering trees. There are several different female colour forms that mimic other, distasteful species of butterfly. The caterpillar feeds on citrus plants, particularly the Pomelo (Citrus maxima).
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is the type specimen of this species, a male caught on the Burma - Thailand border in January 1880. It is named after Colonel C.H.E Adamson, who discovered it. It is a distinctive member of the swallowtail family with a very limited range in the forests of Burma and northern Thailand. Females are larger and paler in colour than males. This species is highly sought after by collectors due to its rarity.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a large and very distinctive species which is found throughout South East Asia, from North East India to China and the Indonesian islands. Its found in lowland forested areas throughout the region, and there are many subspecies. The caterpillar feeds on a variety of plants in the Birthwort family.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly lives in lowland rainforests throughout central Africa, from Sierra Leone to Kenya, although this specimen was caught in Uganda. It is a large and brightly coloured butterfly which is extremely unpalatable. This means that it tastes very bad to predators. Because of this, it flies low in the air and very slowly so that it can show off its distinctive orange markings. These act as a warning to any potential predators that it is not a good meal.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The female of this species has distinctive black with white markings. Interestingly, because this species is avoided by predators many other butterfly species mimic it. These mimics have similar colours and markings and, because of this similarity, predators often confuse them with the bad tasting B. macarista, and avoid eating them. Due to the differences between the male and female of this species, some of the mimic species copy the female and other species copy the male.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The female of this species is less colourful than the male, but is still very impressive. These large butterflies live in the forests of the Himalayas, where they feed on a variety of flowers, as well as rotting fruit and even animal dung. Their caterpillars feed on the leaves of Magnolia trees. The Kaiser-I-Hind is very rare - its survival is under threat as the forests it depends on are cut down for firewood and timber.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Kaiser-I-Hind is a spectacular swallowtail butterfly native to montane forests in the eastern Himalayan region and parts of South East Asia. It often lives at very high altitudes, up to 3000m. The spectacular colouring of the male has made it very popular with collectors and populations have been decimated throughout the species' range. All trade in the species is now banned under the CITES convention
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This orange coloured butterfly lives in the forests of Northern India, Burma and much of South East Asia. This specimen was collected in Borneo. The butterflies live in the forest canopy, but males sometimes come down to the forest floor to feed on dung or rotting fruit. The female feeds on nectar, and normally remains high up in the trees.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is a member of the Pieridae family. Most of the butterflies in this family are white or yellow in colour - the more familiar Cabbage White butterfly also belongs to this family. The yellow and orange colours of this species give it its common name, Oranges and lemons. It is found throughout the savannah areas of eastern and southern Africa. Its caterpillars feed on the leaves of plants such as the South African Caper.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is widespread throughout sub-Saharan Africa, where it is found in savannah grassland as well as on farmland and in gardens. Its common English name comes from the distinctive blue patches on its hindwings, which are said to make the butterfly look like a pansy. This specimen was collected in Natal, South Africa.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Common Imperial is a forest butterfly native to much of South East Asia and parts of southern China. It is almost instantly recognisable by the long 'tails' that project from its hind wings. This feature is characteristic of butterflies from the Lycaenid family. Its caterpillars feed on the leaves and flowers of Cinnamon and Ironwood trees.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly lives in the dense rainforest of the Congo basin in equatorial Africa. It doesn't have a common name, but it is part of a group of species called tree nymphs. It looks very similar to the family of small blue and brown butterflies that are commonly called the Blues. It is actually a completely unrelated species which mimics the colour and patterns of a Blue butterfly. Like many of the specimens in this collection, this specimen belonged to Dr Harry Eltringham, who researched mimicry in butterflies.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly lives in the dense tropical forests of India and Sri Lanka. It's very distinctive shape is due to its camouflage technique. When at rest, with its wings folded, the butterfly looks very much like a dead leaf stuck to a branch. The outer surface of its wings is a dark, mottled brown colour. In this way the butterfly avoids being eaten by birds. Many other butterfly species are camouflaged in this way.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Common Green Charaxes is a forest species which is found in the tropical forests of western and central Africa. This specimen was collected in Sierra Leone. Like many other Charaxes butterflies, it will form a swarm around a source of food, like a piece of rotting fruit. The edges of its forewings are serrated, and it uses them to push other butterflies out of the way when feeding.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Despite its name, the female Shining Blue Nymph does not have blue wings, only a pattern of brown marks and broad white stripes. By contrast, the male of the species has highly iridescent wings that appear bright blue in strong sunlight and give the species its common name.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The shining blue nymph is a large forest butterfly from western and central Africa. Neither the male or female of this species has brightly coloured wings, but the male is highly iridescent. This means that, in strong sunlight, his wings appear bright blue.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The common Map butterfly is native to eastern Asia, from India to China and parts of the Malayan Peninsular. It has long hindwings with sharply angular edges which give it an unmistakable appearance. Its name comes from the gridlike pattern of dark lines on its wings which some collectors have compared to the lines on a map.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species lives in the forests of eastern Asia, from north-eastern India, through China and Korea as far as Japan. Here it has been adopted as Japan's National Butterfly. It is a forest species, and feeds on rotting fruit and the sap that oozes from trees. It flies very fast, and its wings make a loud clapping sound in flight.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Charaxes butterflies are found throughout most of Africa. They are large, powerfully flying species that mainly live in forested areas, although they are often encountered in gardens. Unusually, the Savannah Charaxes is found in open grassland areas, as its name suggests. They often form large swarms around food or a source of water, such as a puddle.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Northern Jungle Queen is native to a relatively small area of the forests of northern India and mountainous areas of northern Burma and Thailand. It is a large and conspicuous species - however, it rarely comes down to ground level, and spends most of its time high up in the forest canopy.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This large turquoise coloured butterfly, also known as the Brazilian Morpho, lives in the Amazon basin. Adults feed on rotting fruit and sap leaking from trees. The caterpillar, which is red-brown with bright patches of lime-green, is nocturnal and eats the foliage of the small tree Erythroxylum pilchrum.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Sometimes called the Mother-of-Pearl Morpho, this butterfly, a member of the brightly coloured Morpho genus, has a more subtle iridescent colour than most of the other Morpho species. A pale sheen of iridescence still reveals the underlying pattern of spots and lines. This species tends to occur at higher altitudes than most of the other Morpho species in the genus.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Morpho rhenetor, or Cramer's Blue Morpho, is a large and impressive species that lives in the rainforests of Venezuela, Guyana and Colombia. It's intense blue colour is not due to pigment, but to microscopic ridges in the scales of the wings that only reflect blue light. The intensity of the colour changes with the angle that the wings are held at, producing spectacular flashes of colour as the butterfly flies through the air.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Great Nawab is found in northern India, Nepal and parts of Burma. It's a large species which can often be seen feeding in gardens. It has a caterpillar with large horns protruding from it's head, giving it a very strange appearance. The caterpillar feeds on the leaves of the Hackberry.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is found throughout eastern Asia, although it is not particularly common. It is a forest species, and like all Crows has dark colouration with an iridescent sheen on its wings. It is sometimes seen feeding on flowers in gardens and suburban areas, where its caterpillars are believed to feed on Oleander bushes.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Dusky Diadem is a common and widespread forest dwelling species. It is often found in clearings or near water. Both sexes are similarly coloured dark brown and have a row of eye spots on each hind wing. It can be found from Assam in north east India through Burma, Vietnam, Laos and Thailand, to Malaysia and the islands of Indonesia.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a forest butterfly that is found in undisturbed rainforest throughout Indo-china and the islands of Indonesia. There are 4 sub-species. This specimen belongs to the binghami sub-species, which only occurs in the Tennasserim and Ataran Valley regions of southern Burma. The adults feed on nectar, and the caterpillars feed on various species of climbing plant including Rattan vines.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Scarce Catseye is native to South East Asia from Assam in Northern India to Indo-China. This butterfly is the type specimen for the subspecies adamsoni. It was collected by Colonel C.H.E Adamson in Burma in September 1888, and is only found in the forests of Assam and Nagaland in India and in parts of northern Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is only found in a small area of North East India and Burma. It lives in the rainforest, and is relatively rare. The female, seen here from below, is slightly larger than the male, and has a row of eyespots along the bottom edge of the hind wings.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is found in the jungles of South East Asia from Assam to Thailand. This is the type specimen of the sub-species Burmensis, which is only found in Burma. It was caught near Aloungdau Kathapa Pagoda in the Chindwin district of Burma in February 1892 by Colonel C.H.E Adamson. It is very uncommon and is found in scattered locations throughout the region, always in close association with palm trees.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species ranges from Northern India to Sumatra. There are several sub-species. The sub-species elymnias patna patnoides is endemic to Burma. Like all palmflies, its larvae feed on the leaves of various species of palm tree, including the Coconut palm. It flies with a slow flapping and gliding motion, and often lands on leaves after each short flight. It prefers shady areas and is usually found flying under the cover of trees and amongst the undergrowth.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is a large and rare butterfly with dramatic striped markings on its wings. Elymnias nesaea timandra is found in Burma, Thailand and Laos as well as parts of China. The name Palmfly is given to the butterflies in the genus Elymnias because their caterpillars feed on species of Palm. The caterpillar of the Tiger Palmfly feeds on Calamus vines, Chinese Windmill Palm (Trachycarpus forturei) and the Coconut palm (Cocos nucifera).
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is widespread in South East Asia from Sri Lanka to China, Thailand and Malaysia. it is also a popular species in butterfly houses all over the world. In the wild It is generally found in forest areas, often near water. The caterpillars feed on species of Passiflora vine, such as Adenia palmata, and Giloya, Tinospora cordifolia, a climbing plant that is also used in traditional Indian medicine.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Scarce White Commodore, as its name suggests, is a rare butterfly found in parts of southern Asia. It is restricted to higher altitudes, and can be found in the Himalayan hill forests of northern India, Nepal and Bhutan as well as mountainous regions of Burma, Thailand and Malaysia. This specimen was collected in northern Burma in the late 19th century.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is widespread throughout eastern Asia from China to Thailand, Malaysia and the Indonesian islands. This butterfly is the type specimen for the sub-species adamsoni, which occurs in forested regions of Assam and parts of Burma. It was collected in northern Burma during the mid 19th century.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This small butterfly is native to South East Asia, including Burma, southern China and parts of Malaysia. It is sometimes seen feeding at ground level but will take refuge in the forest canopy when threatened. It hides from predators by sitting upside down on the underside of a leaf. This specimen was collected in Burma in the late 19th century by Colonel C.H.E Adamson, who remarked that it was a very common species.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Yellow Pansy is a very widespread species, which is found in Africa and Madagascar as well as most of Eastern Asia. It is an uncommon species that is most often found in grassland and open countryside, often near water. The caterpillar feeds on various aquatic plants in the genus Hygrophila and the Phillipine Violet, Baleria christata.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Leopard Lacewing is a forest species that is found throughout South East Asia from India to Thailand. It is seen in forested areas, often in large numbers, particularly after the rainy season, when flocks of hundreds can gather in some areas. It is also sometimes seen in gardens and alongside roads. The adults feed on nectar from flowers, whilst the caterpillars feed on Passionflower vines.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is the type specimen for this species. This means that it is the first individual of this species to be scientifically described. It was collected by Colonel C.H.E Adamson in Burma during the late 19th century and is named after him. Haridra adamsoni lives in rainforest areas. The adults feed mainly on nectar, whilst the caterpillars feed on the leaves and flowers of several species of vine.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is from Burma. It was collected by Colonel C.H.E. Adamson, who lived in Burma from 1867 to 1895.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is relatively uncommon, and is found in rainforest areas throughout Indo-china and the Indonesian islands. The adults fly high in the forest canopy, and so are normally only seen when they congregate around a source of food, such as rotting fruit. The caterpillars feed on the leaves of plants in the Tamarind family.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This large forest species occurs from Assam in north east India as far as Malaysia and the islands of the Indonesian archipelago. There are several sub-species, and this specimen belongs to the sub-species sandakanus, which is found from Assam in India to Burma. The large, nocturnal caterpillar feeds on the leaves of various species of rainforest tree.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Great Nawab is found throughout southern Asia and parts of Indo-china. It is common in both forested and more disturbed habitats such as agricultural areas. The caterpillar, which is very large and bright green in colour feeds on the leaves of plants in the Rubiaceae family, particularly Ulmaceae celtis.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is found throughout South East Asia, from northern India to Indonesia. It is a large, powerful flyer and normally lives high in the forest canopy, rarely coming down to the forest floor. The female is normally larger than the male. The caterpillar of this species is unmistakable as it has 4 large horns on its head. It is nocturnal, and feeds on the leaves and fruit of the Rambutan (Nephelium lappaceum).
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Jewelled Nawab is native to a large area of South East Asia, from Assam in India to Indo-China and Borneo. It is a large species that normally lives high in the rainforest canopy, rarely coming down to ground level. It is a fast and powerful flyer. The nocturnal caterpillar is large and bright green.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a large forest species native to much of mainland South East Asia and the Malay peninsular. Unusually, the underside of the wings in this species are more heavily patterned than the upper side, with russet spots and streaks.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Pasha is a large forest butterfly that can be found from India to Thailand. It is normally encountered relatively close to the ground - it is a very rapid flyer and rarely settles. When it does, it normally keeps its wings closed. This specimen was collected in Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Courtesan is a widespread species that can be found in rainforests throughout South East Asia, from Assam in north east India to Borneo in Indonesia and the Philippines. Because it occurs over such a large area there are several distinct sub-species. The caterpillar feeds on a wide variety of plants including a number of species of Nettle.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Painted Courtesan occurs throughout India and as far east as Thailand. It is a strikingly patterned species that can be found in a variety of forest habitats. The adults feed mainly on nectar, whilst the caterpillars feed exclusively on the foliage of the Gunpowder Tree, Trema orientalis. This specimen was collected in Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is a member of the large Nymphalid family. It lives in South East Asia, from Assam to Malaysia and Guangdong province in southern China. Although it isn't clear from the photo, the wings are iridescent blue in strong sunlight. Its a forest species that flies very rapidly, often settling with its wings open. It is very common in some parts of its range.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is a medium sized species with a wingspan of about 6cm. It belongs to a large group of butterflies in the Nymphalidae family known as the Baron butterflies. This species is found throughout Burma, Thailand and peninsular Malaysia, and there are several sub-species. This sub-species is only found in parts of southern Burma and Thailand.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Peacock butterfly is so called because of the eye-shaped spots on the wings - rather like the eyes on the tail of a Peacock. The Peacock is one of the species you might see flying around Buddleia bushes in Summer.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Nymphalidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Small tortoiseshell butterfly is the most common red-coloured butterfly in northeast England. It is easily identified because of the yellow streaks on the front wings and blue spots along the edges of the wings. The caterpillars eat stinging nettle leaves.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Nymphalidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Painted Lady is a migrant butterfly, and every year they come to northeast England from the South. It is one of the species you might see near a Buddleia bush in Summer. You can identify Painted Ladies by the salmon-pink colour and by the white spots on the front wings.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Nymphalidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Red Admiral the darkest of our red butterflies. The name 'admiral' has nothing to do with the sea: it is a contraction of 'admirable'. The caterpillars feed on stinging nettles, living between folded leaves.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Nymphalidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Although it is commonly called the 'cabbage white', the Large White is only one of our cabbage-feeding species. The caterpillars feed openly on cabbage leaves, stripping them to skeletons. The adults are distinctly larger than the Small White, and the black marks on the front of the wings are larger.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Although it is commonly called the 'cabbage white', the Small White is only one of our cabbage-feeding species. The caterpillars feed in the heart of the cabbage, later moving out and resting on the midribs of the leaves. The adults are distinctly smaller than the Large White, and the black marks on the front of the wings are smaller.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Green-veined White butterfly is easily identified by the broad greenish 'veins' on the wings. Unlike some of its close relatives, the caterpillars don't feed on cabbages, but instead on wild Crucifers, usually in damp places.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The male Orange Tip butterfly is very distinctive, with the large orange patch on the front wings. The females are similar in most respects to the males, but don't have the orange patches. They are active earlier in the year than most species, and you will see them mainly in mid May. The caterpillars feed on the flowers and seed pods of tall Crucifer plants.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The male Orange Tip butterfly is very distinctive, with the large orange patch on the front wings. The females are similar in most respects to the males, but don't have the orange patches. They are active earlier in the year than most species, and you will see them mainly in mid May. The caterpillars feed on the flowers and seed pods of tall Crucifer plants.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & Pieridae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Every Autumn, people phone their local museums to say they have seen large insects looking like scorpions. The insects are invariably adults of the 'Devil's Coach Horse', a large beetle which curls its tail over its head in a threatening posture. The beetle has sharp jaws and can bite, so the 'painful' end is not the tail but the head.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Coleoptera & Staphylinidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: One common enquiry to museums in Spring and Autumn is from people who have seen a large green triangular insect. This is the Hawthorn Shieldbug, which is the most common British shield-shaped insect. The adults feed on Hawthorn berries before finding a sheltered place to spend the Winter. They become active in Spring, and lay eggs. The young ones grow gradually through the Summer.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Hemiptera & Acanthosomatidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is found in the rainforests of South East Asia. The adult butterflies feed mainly on nectar from flowers, but also feed on rotting fruit and dung. The caterpillars feed on the leaves of the Litchi tree, Litchi chinensis. The male and female of this species look very different - the male is smaller and has large blue patches on its hindwings.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is native to South East Asia, where it is found in forest areas from southern China to Borneo. The female, seen here, is larger than the male, and has broader and more rounded wings. It is also less brightly coloured. This specimen was collected in Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is found throughout South East Asia, from India to the islands of Indonesia and the Philippines. It is found in both primary and secondary rainforest. The adults feed on nectar and also on rotting fruit and dung. Small groups can sometimes be found feeding around puddles on the forest floor. The caterpillars of this species feed on a variety of plants in the Loranthus family as well as the shrub Elytranthe cochinchinensis.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Knight is a fairly common species found throughout South East Asia, from Assam to Sumatra. It is frequently found along the edges of woods, in open country or secondary growth. Often it is seen flying rather weakly around flowering bushes where it settles with outspread wings. It is locally common, such as in the Chiang Mai area of northern Thailand. There are several sub-species.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a rapid flying species which is more common to highland areas of south east Asia. It can be found in the Himalayas of north east India, in Burma and parts of southern china. It makes short flights, often landing on vegetation with its wings held out flat. The caterpillar feeds on euphorbia plants in the genus Glochidion.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This species is a fast flying, large butterfly that is frequently seen around flowering trees and shrubs from China to Burma, Thailand and Malaysia. Females are normally larger than males. Like most other sergeant butterflies, it frequently holds its wings out flat when at rest on vegetation. The caterpillar feeds on the woody shrub Randia canthiodes.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Grey Pansy is a common species normally found in grassland areas throughout eastern Asia, flying over open ground in bright sunlight. The adults are normally solitary and feed on flowering bushes. It is very adaptable to human environments and can often be seen in gardens and farmland areas. There are different seasonal forms in some parts of its range - in Malaysia there is a dry season form and a wet season form.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Straight Line Map Wing is found from Assam to Borneo, including parts of Thailand and Peninsular Malaysia. In Burma during the 19th Century, when this specimen was collected by Colonel C.H.E Adamson, it was very uncommon. Its preferred habitat is rainforests free from human disturbance. Its caterpillar's major foodplant is Tetracera sarmentosa - a woody climbing plant with large leaves, as well as various species of Fig.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is was collected in Burma, but can be found throughout South East Asia from Assam in northern India as far east as China and south to Sri Lanka and Indonesia. It lives in very wet, lowland rainforest. It is a large species that is very slow flying and is frequently seen at ground level in the forest, feeding on fruit or flowering plants. The caterpillars feed on the leaves and fruit of several species of Fig tree.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This colourful species is found throughout Assam, Burma and the Malay Peninsular. This species is smaller and has rounder wings than most other members of this genus. It is a forest species and normally occurs near pools and streams in scattered locations. However, it is normally common in those areas where it is found. The caterpillar feeds on species of Fig.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Wizard is a large butterfly native to the rainforests of South east Asia. This specimen is from Burma. It lives in rainforest areas throughout the region, where the adults feed on mainly on nectar. The males can sometimes be observed congregating around dung or puddles on the forest floor. The caterpillars feed on the foliage of the rainforest tree, Poikilospermum suaveolens.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This large species is found throughout South East Asia and in parts of northern Australia. The adults fly in the understorey of the rainforest, feeding mainly on nectar. The caterpillars, which are black with orange and white markings on their sides, feed on the leaves of native Petunia (Ruella ripens) and Dipteracanthus bracteatus. This specimen is from Burma.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is from Burma. It was collected by Colonel C.H.E. Adamson, who lived in Burma from 1867 to 1895. The Diadem is a very widespread species, living in South America, North America and Africa as well as southeast Asia. The females occur in a number of different colour patterns, but the males are all very similar.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Diadem is a widespread species found in the tropics all over the world. The male has unremarkable black and white markings on the upper surface of it's wings, but unusually the underside, seen here, is more colourful.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This butterfly is extremely widespread, with a global distribution in the tropics - Africa, South East Asia, South America as well as parts of the southern United States. Females come in a variety of colour morphs that mimic the patterns of the poisonous Monarch butterfly Danaus chrysippus. The adults feed on nectar from flowers whilst the caterpillars feed on a wide variety of plants.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Lepidoptera & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Great Silver Diving Beetle is Britain's largest water beetle. Its silvery appearance when in water is given by the layer of air that the beetle carries trapped in tiny hairs on its underside and under its wing cases. This allows it to breathe, but it has to return to the surface regularly to renew its air supply. It feeds on decaying plant material as an adult, but as a larva it is carnivorous and feeds on snails.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Coleoptera & Hydrophiliidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Stag Beetle is Britain's largest insect. The 'antlers' that give the beetle its name are in fact massive jaws. Only the male has these, and they are used to fight other males during the breeding season when the beetles are in competition for mates. The Stag Beetle is found in Southern England and at a few sites in Wales, but was once much more widespread. Conservation efforts are underway to try and safeguard the current population.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Coleoptera & Scarabaeidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Rose Chafer is a large and attractive beetle which is active in sunny weather. The adults can normally be found from May to September every year. They live amongst vegetation, and feed on foliage, fruit and flowers. They are often found feeding on roses, hence their common name.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Coleoptera & Scarabaeidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Beautiful Demoiselle is a relatively rare damselfly in the UK, and can be found alongside faster flowing rivers and streams with sandy or pebbly bottoms. The males defend small teritiories in bankside vegetation using their brightly coloured bodies and dark wings to attract mates. They fly with a short fluttering flight, rather like a butterfly.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Odonata & Calopterygidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Water Stick Insect is an aquatic bug that lives in shallow water with lots of vegetation. Its long thin body helps it to disguise itself amongst underwater plants as it lies in wait for small insect larvae, worms and water fleas, which it catches in its long front legs. The water stick insect is relatively common in the UK but its camouflage makes it hard to spot.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Hemiptera & Nepidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Honey Bee is perhaps one of the most familiar insects - kept by people for its honey for thousands of years. This specimen is a queen, and can be told apart from the worker bees by her much longer abdomen, more golden brown colouring and longer legs.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Hymenoptera & Apidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Hornet is the largest social wasp in Europe. In Britain it is uncommon and generally confined to southern England. It builds nests in holes in trees or buildings during the summer. A fully formed colony can contain as many as 2000 hornets. They have an extremely painful sting that has been likened to an injection from a red hot needle. Luckily they are not aggressive, and will only sting if threatened.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Hymenoptera & Vespidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: The Dark Bush Cricket is a common species which can be found in hedgerows, rough grassland and areas of wasteland throughout central and southern areas of Britain. This specimen is a female, easily distinguished by her long curved ovipositor, which she uses to lay her eggs into the soil. The Dark Bush Cricket has small wings that cannot be used for flight. However, the male produces a song by rubbing them together to make a chirping noise.
SciName: Arthropoda & Insecta & Orthoptera & Tettigoniidae : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: This is a piece of coral from the Indian Ocean, preserved in 'spirit' (a mixture of ethanol and methanol). Spirit preserves of the soft parts of an animal which would otherwise shrivel away, but the specimens often quickly lose their colour. Jars of spirit used to be common in museum displays, but they are becoming much rarer.
SciName: & & : : : : Coelenterata

NarNarrative: This is a piece of coral from the Indian Ocean, preserved in 'spirit' (a mixture of ethanol and methanol). Spirit preserves of the soft parts of an animal which would otherwise shrivel away, but the specimens often quickly lose their colour. Fragile specimens, like this coral, often survive longer when protected in a spirit jar.
SciName: : : : : Coelenterata

NarNarrative: This is a spider preserved in 'spirit' (a mixture of ethanol and methanol). Spirit preserves of the soft parts of an animal which would otherwise shrivel away, but the specimens often quickly lose their colour. This spider is a native of the Canary Islands, but was found in the Bigg Market in newcastle on 28 September 1907: it probably arrived in a box of bananas.
SciName: Arthropoda & Arachnida & & : : : : Arthropoda

NarNarrative: Limpets are a very common and widespread species found all along Britain's coast. They are most often seen tightly fixed to the rocks, as they prefer to feed when they are immersed in water. When exposed, they seal a small amount of water inside their shell and grip onto the rock to prevent themselves drying out. Limpets feed on seaweed and algae. They are an important source of food for many larger predators including sea anemones, crabs and shore birds.
SciName: Mollusca & & & : : : : Mollusca
